reviewText: Just Kidding. No, really, I'm writing a review for Star Trek: Voyager (ST-V). I had never been interested in Sci-Fi untill my bro-inlaw introduced me to Star Trek: The Next Generation. It was cool and all, but I have never had a TV Show hit me harder than ST-V. It has it all: suspence, drama, sexuality (BIG PLUS, especialy 7 o' 9), special effects, action, things that blow up, and suprises that will blow you away. I highly recomend ST-V, But it doesn't really get that good untill season 4. Then again, thats when 7 o' 9 came on the show (5 stars on her, too).

Note:  This is more of a commentary on the show than on the upcoming DVD.  But I hope it will help you in your decision to purchase Season One of Star Trek Voyager.
As of this date, I have only seen the packaging for the Voyager DVDs.  I'm not sure how the material is being presented.  But rest assured, Star Trek: Voyager's debut on DVD has been a long time in coming.  Many Trek fans have criticized Voyager for being aimless, the stories lifeless, the cast unlikable, too much Borg here, too little of this there.  The fact is, not everyone is going to enjoy what Voyager was offering.  Not everyone enjoyed Deep Space Nine (although it's a brilliant series), and not everyone is currently appreciating Enterprise for what it is.  As for myself, I happen to disagree with all of the negative criticisms.  In my opinion, I believe Voyager to be one of the strongest series, next to Deep Space Nine, in the entire Trek canon.  Every show has weak stories - not every show has a cast with an incredible chemistry.  Not every show has a story arch that persists for 7 solid years.  Not every show puts a woman in a commanding, leading role and manages to succeed as a character/captain, where others have faltered.  Voyager does all of this, and more.  It takes Roddenberry's vision of exploration and makes it the central focus.  In essence, this is Lost in Space, with a Starfleet crew.
For 7 exhilarating seasons, we join two crews (Starfleet and Maquis) who are unnervingly forced to work together as one, as they truly go where no one has gone before.  Thrown 70 thousand light years across the galaxy into the Delta quadrant, it's up to the intrepid crew of the highly advanced, intrepid-class starship Voyager to work together and confront a slew of new alien races, civilizations, and intricate conflicts in order to safely return home.  It's not always smooth sailing, and if you think you know how they make it back to Earth, think twice.  The number of riveting, edge-of-your-seat two-parters are plentiful and serve as captivating examples of how *great* Trek stories should be told.  It's truly a story of change.  The characters grow and develop into people you'll swear you know inside and out, and by the end of the show, you'll feel as if you made a `trek' across the Delta quadrant yourself.
The spectrum of Star Trek: Voyager is both broad and brilliant.  It has an epic quality that builds and builds each season.  I've grown to love every crew in each Trek series, but Voyager's crew is one that will hold a special place in my heart, always.
I suspect Paramount will do just as good, if not a better job on these than the Deep Space Nine discs.  If they come anywhere close, fans of the series should not be disappointed.
Everyone, get ready for the journey - all over again.  If you missed the show the first time around, you're in for an awesome treat!

Less than one year following the concluding season of "Star Trek: The Next Generation" in 1994, executive producer/writer Rick Berman, along with Michael Piller and Jeri Taylor, created a fourth television series based upon the "Star Trek" universe created by Gene Roddenberry (1921-1991) in the 1960's. This fourth television series, entitled "Voyager" (which is the name of the Federation of Planets starship used in the series), first aired in January 1995, and ran for seven seasons until it concluded in May, 2001.  Because "Voyager" aired initially in the month of January (instead of the traditional September), only 16 episodes were filmed for the first season.  The succeeding six other seasons had 26 episodes each, for a grand total of 172 episodes for the entire series.
Unlike the previous three "Star Trek" television series, which (for the most part) took place within the bounds of the Federation of Planets (or in nearby sovereign areas of space, such as the Klingon Empire or the Romulan Empire) in the Alpha Quadrant, the starship Voyager is hurled tens of thousands of light-years from home into the previously unknown and unexplored Delta Quadrant, which is located at the far side of the Milky Way Galaxy.  Even while travelling at warp 8 (the fastest safe speed that a typical starship can travel), it would take Voyager several decades to return to Earth.  Hence, the series focuses on the survival of Voyager's Starfleet crew, who are completely isolated and unable to even maintain normal communications with Earth, as well as the crew's ultimate desire to find a way home faster than their ship is capable of doing.  Also, along the way, Voyager adopts a few Delta Quadrant natives.
The primary cast members of the first season of "Voyager" include Captain Catherine Janeway (Kate Mulgrew), Commander Chakotay (Robert Beltran), the half-Klingon Lt. B'Elanna Torres (Roxann Dawson), Delta Quadrant native (Ocampan) Kes (Jennifer Lien), Lt. Thomas Eugene Paris (Robert Duncan McNeill), Delta Quadrant native (Talaxian) Neelix (Ethan Phillips), the holographic Emergency Medical Holographic Program (a.k.a., "The Doctor", played by Robert Picardo), the Vulcan Lt. Cmdr. Tuvok (Tim Russ) and Ensign Harry Kim (Garrett Wang).  In the two-part series opener entitled "The Caretaker", Chakotay, B'Elanna, Seska (Martha Packett) and a few other occasional Voyager crewmen were not part of the original Voyager crew.  Instead, they were members of the Maquis, a group of armed separatists opposed to both Federation and Cardassian rule.  They, along with the crew of Voyager (who is sent to capture them), are themselves captured by a very advanced being known only as the Caretaker, who uses his technology to grab and transport them to the Delta Quadrant.  The transportation damages Voyager and the Maquis ship and leaves many Voyager crewmen dead.  Rather than let a less advanced, but violent, race known as the Kazon obtain the ailing Caretaker's technology, Captain Janeway makes the unpopular decision to destroy the Caretaker's ship, which also destroys their best & easiest chance of getting home quickly.  Hence, Voyager is on its own in the Delta Quadrant, having no support from the Federation, and begins its long journey back home with a combined Federation/Maquis/Delta Quadrant-native crew.
Through the first season, Voyager continues to battle the Kazon (who are determined to own its technology), the unfriendly holographic Doctor (the only doctor on board) starts to become more sentient and friendly thanks to his interactions with Kes, a traitor is on the loose, the phage-infected Vidians want to harvest Voyager crewman organs, the crew experiences time travel, the crew have to acquire a taste for Neelix's cooking, and B'Elanna experiences inner battle between her human and Klingon halves.  Noteworthy episodes include the two-part "The Caretaker", "Time and Again", "Phage", "The Cloud", "Eye of the Needle", "Emanations", "Faces", "Jetrel" and "Learning Curve".
Overall, I rate the first season of "Voyager" with 4 out of 5 stars.  It was a good start for what ultimately became a much better series after the introduction of the former Borg character "Seven of Nine" (Jeri Ryan) at the end of the third season.  I am very glad to see Paramount Television finally begin releasing the "Voyager" series on DVD.

This set of DVDs includes all 15 episodes from the first season, exclusive featurettes and bonus material. The episodes are in full screen format (widescreen would have been nice - hence 4 stars. Of course, since it wasn't originally created in widescreen format, this full-screen format is understandable) with newly remixed Dolby Digital English 5.1 tracks and English Dolby Surround.  The episodes from season one are:
Disc 1:
Caretaker - The series premier. While Voyager is in pursuit of a Maquis ship, both vessels disappear into an area known as the badlands where an unknown phenomenon sends both ships into the Delta quadrant.  There they suddenly appear on what appears to be a farm but is really a laboratory in orbit around a planet. Two crewmembers are missing and Captain Janeway follows a signal from the laboratory to a planet where they find the missing crewmembers.  But how did they get there and why were they there?
Parallax - Voyager encounters and area of space with heavy spatial distortions where they come across a ship that is trapped in the event horizon of a collapsed star.  Voyager unsuccessfully tries to rescue the ship but can't by itself and speeds off to try to find help.  But as they head away from the star they realise they're heading right back to it! They must come up with a plan to escape from this anomoly.
Time and Again - While investigating the source of a disasterous shockwave encountered by Voyager, memers of the crew are transported back in time to the day before the shockwave was created.  Trying to get back to their ship before the disaster occurs, they encounter a group of protesters outside a government polaric ion power station who plan on destroying the facility. One of the worst Voyager characters, Kes, plays an important role in this mission with her "latent Ocampan psychic abilities."
Disc 2:
Phage - During an away mission, the other weak character from Voyager (but still better than Kes), Neelix is attacked and apparently killed.  When found by his crewmates it was discovered that his lungs had been removed. The Doctor is able to implant holographic lungs that keep him alive but confined to sick bay.  Another away mission is sent to find out what happened and they discover a medical lab full of organs from different species.  Just then Voyager detects an alien vessel leaving orbit and Voyager takes off in pursuit.
The Cloud - Voyager explores a nebula rich in omicron particles, which might prove useful for the ship's energy reserves. But when Voyager enters the nebula, it encounters an energy barrier that brings the ship to a dead stop. Breaking through, the ship continues its penetration of the nebula and are attacked by organisims that attach themselves to the hull and begin draining energy from Voyager...
Eye of the Needle - Voyager encounters a wormhole that might take them back to the alpha quadrant but it's too small for the entire ship to enter so a probe is sent through.  The probe gets stuck in a gravitational anomoly before making it through but is being scanned by someone on the other side of the wormhole.  Janeway orders a message be sent via the probe and the receive a reply from the aplha quadrant...
Ex Post Facto - While on an away mission assiting a scientist repair some equiment on the Banean homeworld, Paris was convicted of the murder of the scientist and his punishment is to relive the crime from his victim's perspective every 14 hours.  Janeway sets out to discover what happened.
Disc 3:
Emanations - Chakotay, Kim and Torres beam down to a cavern in an asteroid and discover what appears to be an alien burial ground.  While taking sensor readings, a "dimensional distortion" forms and beings to fill the cavern. The away teams beams back to Voyager but Kim isn't transported back - in his place is the body of a deceased alien.
Prime Factors - The crew takes some R&R on a planet full of hospitality.  There they discover the inhabitants have a device that can fold space, allowing travel to places even as remote as 40,000 light years away.  This could be the crew's chance to get back to Earth.  But will the Prime Directive prevent obtaining it?
State of Flux - While searching for food on a planet, a Kazon ship is detected in orbit.  After a brief conflict between away teams the Voyager crew makes it back safely and breaks orbit.  A few days later a Kazon distress signal is received and Janeway feels obligated to respond.  It turns out to be the same Kazon ship encountered in orbit at the planet they just visted and there is only one surviving member of the Kazon crew. The weapon signatures indicate Federation technology was used in the destruction, but how?  While investigating the cause of the destruction, another Kazon vessel arrives in response to the distress signal...
Heroes and Demons - Ensign Kim in trapped in a holodeck simulation of Beowulf during a freak accident involving beaming samples of a protostar onto Voyager.  Tuvok and Chakotay "disappear" when sent in to try and bring Kim out and the captain won't risk any more humans so she sends the Doctor in to save the missing crew memembers.
Disc 4:
Cathexis - Tuvok and Chakotay are attacked in a shuttlecraft by an unknown entity that drains the bio-neural energy from the Chakotay's brain.  Upon recovering on Voyager, members of the crew being to act strangely - Paris alters the ship's course without knowing or remembering had had done so and Torres initiates a warp core shutdown without knowing it.  Examinations by the Doctor reveal alien entity had seized control of their minds to force them to do these things.  Janeway transfers all command and control functions to the only non-organic crew member, the Doctor, as a precaution while they investigate what's happening.
Faces - When members of an away team disappear on a planet, another away team is sent to investigate.  They locate the other team in a cave but can't penitrate a force field protecting the cave.  One member of the missing away team is Torres and it becomes obvious that she's part of an experiment when suddenly there is an all-Klingon Torres and an all-human Torres.
Jetrel - Neelix is surprised when a Haakonian scientist responsible for the conquest of Neelix's homeworld suddenly wants to meet with Neelix.  Apparently, this scientist and Neelix were both exposed to high levels of metreon isotopes which endanger the lives of all members of both species.  The Haakonian has only days to live and wants to take blood samples from Neelix and use Voyager's technology to work on a cure for both races.  But is this is true intent?
Learning Curve - When a member of the crew from the original Maquis crew disrupts the ship's power by making an unauthorized repair, Janeway decides the Maquis crew members need formalized Starfleet training and tasks Tuvok with the job.  Tuvok's unemotional drill-camp begins to put the "cadets" on the verge of rebellion while the ship's bio-gel packs begin suffering from a disease that must be eradicated before spreading to all of the ship's systems.
Disc 5:
Special Features - The typical mix of actor interviews and "how did they do that" special effects segments.

Star Trek Voyager. I never really liked Star Trek before I saw Voyager. I was just channel surfing one day, when I came across the pilot episode, through some stroke of luck. The very first minute, I was hooked. From what bits and pieces of TNG I had seen, this was a great change. For one, it had a female captain. And Voyager also used CGI more beautifully than any other Trek I've seen. I love this series because it portrays human values and emotions in a true and touching way. Voyager is stranded 70,000 light years from home when they are pulled across space by a strange array by an entity called the Caretaker. When the Caretaker dies, he makes Captain Janeway promise that she will destroy the array before it falls into the wrong hands. Captain Janeway keeps her promise, leaving them with no way home. As they make their way across the Delta Quadrant, we see how they survive in an uncharted part of space while staying true to their morals and values. They take in other individuals into their crew, like Seven of Nine, and her struggle to regain her humanity is extremely well portrayed. Special moments like the first time Voyager gets to speak to their loved ones back home are really moving. Voyager is truly an amazing series - My mother, who was a total trek-hater, was hooked and never missed a single episode after watching one episode of Voyager. My friends, who scoffed at Star Trek, became die hard Voyager fans. There was a rumor that Paramount might not release Voyager on DVD, and I was truly upset that that might happen. Thanks Paramount, for deciding to release Voyager on DVD! I cant wait !! :) I'm so happy :)

On January 16, 1995, Star Trek Voyager launched into TV history with Season One. Clearly the best series of the Star Trek franchise, due in large part to an outstanding cast, led by the great Kate Mulgrew as Captain Kathryn Janeway. In Season One, we meet the crew as they are thrust into the Delta Quadrant, 70,000 light years from Earth, and watch two ships of enemies, Star Fleet and Marquis, band together to begin thier perilous journey home. Sporting superb visual effects, excellent writing by Brannon Braga and Jeri Taylor, and one of the best theme songs ever written for television, Star Trek Voyager is a timeless masterpiece of science fiction and human drama.

"Voyager" is perhaps the least appreciated show in the "Star Trek" franchise.
Critics have complained about the characters and the storylines for years and yet for those of us who enjoyed the series (and now own DVDs of it) there are many things to love about the years-long journey the ship and its crew took. Chief among them is the fact that it harkened back to the original series in its willingness to confront social issues in the context of a science fiction program. Gender equality, racial equality, religious tolerance, the rights of people to protest what they consider to be unfair treatment and other issues were dealt with in much the same way that Captain James T. Kirk and the crew of the "Enterprise" did and that made "Voyager" interesting to watch.
The cast, headed by Kate Mulgrew as the captain of "Voyager" was first rate and the special effects were state of the art for the time period. Since then CGI has made enormous strides so those special effects seem somewhat dated now, but they still stand the test of time in my opinion. Besides, the show did not depend upon those special effects to drive its stories. It was top-flight writing that did that.
For my money, "Voyager" was a great series and truly representative of those qualities that have made the "Star Trek" franchise an enduring part of television history.

I think time has a way of making us change our perspectives on art ... in this case, a television series. When "Star Trek Voyager" was running its course on television, I was not really impressed with it. Its story line didn't actually fit with my mental map of the Star Fleet Universe. I was still in the Original Series mode. That to me was "Star Trek". Now, after a few decades, it is like I am seeing it for the very first time. Not just Voyager, but TNG and DS9 as well. There is a lot more depth to the characters than what I originally gave credit for. So, after running a few of the Original Series, I find that I prefer STV, DS9, and TNG. They are a whole lot better than what I remember.

I remember the difficulty I had watching this show immediately after the long running Next Generation essentially redefined the Star Trek brand. Where Next Generation was born of confidence (staffed by the best of the best) and interstellar cooperation (look ... a Klingon on the bridge), Voyager was born out of an espionage mission and the resulting betrayals and chaos. Captain Janeway was weak where Captain Picard was unwaverable. Security went from the primal and visceral Worf to the emotionless and intellectual Tuvok. It was a cast of rogues, traitors and neophytes. Back then I just couldn't stick with it. Now, I have returned to the series and appreciate it much more because there is no need to compare it to Next Generation or to expect it to somehow proceed from Next Generation. It turn out that it stands on its own pretty well. Season 1 is mostly an investment in backgound necessary to more fully enjoy the improving story ideas in later seasons. Highlights of Season 1 include Episode 14 - Faces where B'Elanna is literally and metaphorically split in half by the Vidiians to explore ideas about self-acceptance, tempering anger for a higher purpose (courage) and outwitting the need for violence as a solution. Also Episode 15 - Jetrel is recommended for the powerful lesson that there is no winner in a nuclear war or similar event of mass destruction.

Lowlights (least worthwhile episodes) include Episode 11 - State of Flux where the entire Voyager security force is outwitted by a single Cardassian it knows to be a traitor, and Episode 13 - Cathexis which is the first of many failed episodes centered on Chakotay and his poorly conceived ideas on Native American spiritualism. Even setting that aside, the premise of a man-eating nebula shows how bad science makes for bad science fiction.

I still cannot tell whether the story writers intended to employ a running joke about Voyager security being less effective than Barney Fyfe. Watch for yourself and decide. It's either exceptionally subtle Star Trek humor of overuse of a plot device. Watch and enjoy better seasons are ahead.

So, please be aware that this is a review from a certain point of view.  That point of view is from a Sci-fi fan in his late 50s.  I actually enjoyed the team work type plots and solutions that the Voyager crew develop and implement.  The show is quite different from the predecessors: SOS, SNG and Enterprise.  Different in that this teamwork extends beyond the craft into the cultures that the crew meets on their way home.  The reality is that some cultures are not interested in working as a team but most, if persuaded adequately, work together.  Even, occasionally, the Borg.

Now I have to say that in all honesty, I did not like the show as a young adult when it first arrived on TV.  Action is used as a last resort and agreeing to disagree is a common theme.

But as an adult I see a lot of value in this type of approach to the Voyager's end goal which is to get home with minimal casualties and more than a few positive relations for the future Federation.

There are some good episodes -- Brad Dourifs little arc in the early seasons is one of the best -- but you'll want to cherrypick. Overall, its a long slog with poor reward. The first wholly enjoyable episodes don't appear until just after the middle of the second season and the show never becomes consistently watchable.

This is the most diverse set of actors -- and somehow the blandest set of characters -- that Rick Berman ever stuffed into a starship.

Neelix comes across like Red Buttons in Space. Mulgrew plays Captain Janeway as though shes channeling Kathryn Hepburn. (Even to the hair.) Roxann Dawson has a tendency to play every scene the same over-excited way. Tuvok is a wind-up Vulcan. Harry Kim and Tom Paris are just nonentities.

Though blessed with a pair of genuinely memorable characters -- Robert Picardos pathologically self-involved holographic doctor and Jennifer Liens tender Kes -- the show over-uses the one and wound up dumping the other for an actress with more obvious charms. (Needless to say, Kes's late-in-the-game return is a standout.)

The only one to emerge with charm largely intact is Robert Beltran.

While the overall concept is novel, it doesnt inform enough of the plots. Most of the stories are just Star Trek filler: The crew over-reaches -- nebula, anomaly, distress call, alien with something up its sleeve -- and the rest of the episode is spent making repairs.

And, speaking of repairs, never has a starship fallen apart more quickly than Voyager.

And pretty much all they do is violate the prime directive.

Ultimately, I did get used to it and with familiarity comes a certain affection.

But its a grudging familiarity and a grudging affection.

And after seven laborious seasons, thats just not enough.

Voyager is a 5 star series, but this review is about the DVD package purchased of the first season. All DVDs are complete and play without any glitches. The images are much clearer and the contrast much sharper than what you get watching Netflix. The animation/CGI sequences are outstanding. The sound is great. There are limited menu options which is to be expected since these are older DVDs.

The DVD "case" is cool to look at but not practical at all. The first DVD has little protection compared to the others. The top and bottom plastic halves of the case slide off up and down, exposing a book-like arrangement of DVDs, all uncovered on the top side. See my photos. The "book" pages protect all but the top DVD. With great care sliding the cover off and on, which tends to catch, I should be able to keep them well protected when accessing the discs.

My biggest gripe is with the menu. It reminds me of the TOS menu. It has cool graphics, sound, and animation with the ship flying into place, one for each episode, followed by your picking the correct ship to access the episode you want. There is no continuous play. Every time an episode ends you have to go back through this entire process to pick the next episode. It's cool once or twice but gets old quickly. If there was an option to see just the episode titles without all the animation that would be great. This format is maddening and frankly a bit juvenille.

I am praying that someday this series will get the recognition it deserves and be released in Blu-ray format. Until then I'll continue to collect all the seasons and put up with this crazy menu. What choice do I have? I love this series.

Voyager is classic sci-fi. It's not the best installment of the Trek universe, but it's amazingly good science fiction.

The show has 1 obvious story arc from start to finish, about the Voyager trying to travel the full length of the galaxy to get back to Earth. But along the way they have plenty of mini adventures where the crew has to pull together despite their differences because they only have each other to rely on.

They face old foes like the Borg (who are everywhere) and friends like Q (because what's a Trek series without Q) and lots of new ones that they meet along the way. The individual episodes remind me of 1950's and 60's sci fi stories, only with much high production value. The show even eludes to it's throwback nature by having one of the characters loving to use the Holodeck to relive bad 1950's sci-fi.

Voyager is a fun departure from the Trek series that proceeded it. It's still "Spacehip flying around meeting aliens" but it's not constantly arguing with the Klingons and Romulans.

It's well worth watching for the fun ride it is.

That being said, Voyager did show glimmers of hope.  I loved many of the characters they introduced.  Janeway and Chakotay's relationship was timeless, and I was pleased to know that they got closer over the seasons.  The Doctor is my favorite character. As the Doctor is on his own quest to become real and human, Voyager is trying to get back to humanity and the Alpha Quandrant.  Neelix was also a pleasant surprise. After "Caretaker" almost nothing was said about the Caretaker's mate/partner who could definitely send them home.  It was as if the first episode didn't happen at all.
The good thing is that the subsequent seasons keep getting better and better.  Overall, Voyager is a great series; it just gets off to a slow start.  Watch the First Season, and if you're like me, and don't really like it, keep watching, because the seasons get better and better.

"Voyager" is my all-time favorite TV series, and I've been watching it since about the turn of the century. (So that's what, fourteen years?) Some might argue that this accounts for my IQ; but I say "Voyager" is a great series!  However, I'm not rating the series here; I'm rating this first season. And Season 1 is...okay.

If I'd started watching "Voyager" from the beginning, I would likely have lost interest pretty quickly. Season 1 is by no means bad, and it has a few fantastic episodes. But the show was still three seasons away from finding its voice. This season is probably better appreciated by someone already familiar with the show, than a "Voyager" virgin.

If you're like me, and became familiar with "Voyager" when it was later in its run, then I would say, watch "Season 1" for the back-story. You'll understand a lot more about the situation and the characters, and it's also great to see how a lot of the characters have changed over the years. B'Elanna, Tom, and Harry especially have the best growth over the years. In the first season they're essentially a trio of adolescents, who "grow up" over the course of the seven-year journey.

To those who've just begun watching "Voyager," I say, stick with it until it gets better. Or, if you haven't the patience, go ahead and skip the first two seasons (for now). The only episode you really need to see in order to understand the later seasons is "Caretaker." For the most part, it's an episodic series, and the few bits of back-story you do need, they do a pretty good job of clarifying in episodes where they become relevant.

The fad nowadays is to watch entire TV shows in airing order. But since "Voyager" is an episodic show, not a serial one, you might find it more fun to just pick and choose random episodes to watch. If you decide to go that route, then I'll recommend a few episodes to keep your eyes peeled for.

First, the plot-moving episodes. That is, episodes you'll want to watch, just so you get an understanding of certain story arcs:

"Caretaker" (The first and most important episode)
"Parallax" (Where certain ranks, namely B'Elanna's, are decided upon)
"Phage" (Which introduces the Vidiians, and shows how Kes becomes nurse)
"State of Flux" (In which Seska's true identity is revealed)

And, episodes to watch just because they're good:

*  All of the above mentioned episodes
"The Cloud" (Rare example of an alien on "Star Trek" that's actually interesting)
"The Eye of the Needle" (Featuring a sympathetic Romulan)
"Prime Factors" (A great moment where some recurring characters get to shine)
"Cathexis" (Chakotay spends most of the episode shirtless)
"Faces" (A must-see for any fan of B'Elanna Torres)
"Learning Curve" (A good "lower-decks" episode, with some unforgettable moments, including Chakotay punching one of his own crewman, and B'Elanna declaring, "Get the cheese to sickbay!")

Where to begin?

The cast has absolutely no chemistry.  None.  I've met paper bags who could deliver lines more convincingly.  The actors seem to have no sense of what their characters' goals are, or their hopes, or dreams, or the gravity of being stuck seventy years from home.  Though this could be because of the show's exceptionally bad writing.

Oh yes.  The writing.  The original series had the Klingons and the Romulans, two technologically powerful and mysterious races bent on the Federation's destruction.  TNG had the Borg, a race of space zombies consuming everything in its path.  DS9 had the Dominion, a sort of anti-Federation powerful enough to cause all the usual Alpha-Quadrant antagonists to ally together in self defense.  In a lot of ways much of Star Trek is defined by the Federation's enemies.

So who does Voyager have?  The Kazon.  If you don't know who they are (they're really forgettable) they look sort of like that guy on the History Channel who claims aliens built the pyramids.  They're nomads, they have no hierarchy and consist of different clans that war for control of, I'm not sure what really, but they shoot at each other as much as everyone else, and their technology is about thirty years behind Voyager's.  Not much of a threat there, but somehow Voyager keeps getting into fights with them for years.  Like, if these people have slow moving ships and yours is much faster and you're moving away from them, shouldn't you stop running into them after a while?

Nope.

So yeah, the writing is bad.  At some point the producers just gave up and started rehashing old TNG plots.  Q shows up, and they take away the best part about TNG by explaining everything about him (ala the new Star Wars trilogy and midichlorians).  They of course encounter the Borg and the producers, wanting to wrap everything up nicely after 44 minutes, make them essentially harmless.  There's never a sense of danger, any indication at all that Voyager might be destroyed, because any time there is a serious threat and Voyager gets the snot kicked out of it you can rest assured that the episode will end with the reset button getting hit.  Be it through time travel, a spatial anomaly, a copy of Voyager, whatever, something will happen such that Voyager will make it through unscathed and marginally closer to the Alpha-Quadrant.

This kind of laziness in writing trickles down to the characters too.  Everyone behaves wildly different from episode to episode.  Some days Janeway gleefully violates the Prime Directive for seemingly trivial reasons.  Other days she's its most stalwart defender.  Also she seems to be an expert on every facet of her ship, to the point where she knows more about Engineering, Science, Operations, and Tactical than the respective heads of those groups.  But it's not just her.  Everyone seems to be an expert on whatever system is needed to advance the plot along with whichever characters just happen to be the room.  Including, hilariously enough, the ship's cook who really should have been thrown out of an airlock the first episode.  Also, the crew of Voyager is made up of Starfleet and Maquis officers and soldiers who just days before had been ready to kill each other, but after like three episodes they're all best buddies.  Shouldn't there have been some mutual loathing, or at the very least, mistrust?

Another example is the technobabble.  Sure Trek has always relied on it but the writers of Voyager didn't know how to make an episode without it.  So rather than seeing the characters grow or change in interesting ways, or the backdrop of the Delta-Quadrant change, we get a bunch of blathering about nucleogenic or polaric or tetrionic or omega particles and blah blah with the neurogenic packs infected and the dylithium reaction failing and on and on and on instead of a plot.

There are occasional moments of decency though.  Robert Picardo has some interesting plots as a hologram slowly becoming more human.  Jeri Ryan, too, plays a former Borg drone rediscovering her individuality and identity.  That said, both of those characters felt like they were little more than ripoffs of Brent Spiner's Data in TNG.

Unless you're a hardcore Trekkie, skip this one.

The original Star Trek was intended as sort of a cross between CAPT Cook's journey of exploration and a western set in space. In many ways, this series is a return to that basic premise. Indeed, the CAPT Cook aspect is pretty strong, the Star ship Voyager is transported in space to a quadrant that will take years, maybe even generations to cross.

However, unlike CAPT Cook, CAPT Janeway has a mixed crew.  The mission that resulted in her ship being stranded in the Delta Quadrant involved chasing a group of insurgents that are fighting the Federation over a treaty that resulted in them losing their colonies to an alien empire. As the crew progresses they pick up a few strays as well. A Borg that has been separated from the collective. A survivor from a destroyed planet. Last but not least, Tom Paris, a former Starfleet officer, turned insurgent, turned informer, who finally freed from his father's expectations and his failures, becomes one of the most important crew members.

While a part of the crew from the beginning, the "Doctor", an Emergency Medical Holographic (EMH) Program, provides the basis for some very important episodes that address the nature of humanity and reality.

Seven of Nine (Jenni Ryan),  a de-assimilated borg, becomes a very interesting character as the series progresses. While I suspect that she was introduced as a character to encourage more teen age boys to watch (Jenni Ryan has a fantastic body and they dress her in skin tight cat suites), she becomes a venue for many interesting stories about what it means to be an adult (she was assimilated by the borg as a young girl and is somewhat immature), what it means to be an individual who is also part of a team, and how one builds meaningful relationships with others.

Chakotay is the commander of the insurgents. He becomes CAPT Janeway's first officer. As a former Starfleet CDR, one suspects that he might have been senior to CAPT Janeway until he left Starfleet to become an insurgent and she got promoted to CAPT. One also get the idea that other than the adventure of Starfleet, he had rebelled against authority and becoming the ship's executive officer was not an easy transition for him.

Many of the early episodes deal with how the Voyager crew finds fuel and food as they cross the Delta Quadrant.  While helpful to the storyline, they aren't always the best episodes. In my humble opinion, the best episodes are in season six.

I recommend this series and will probably watch it again in the future.

This show had sooooo much potential.  The premise: a federation ship lost at the other end of the galaxy --- excellent.  The crew: Maquis and Federation staff having to work together to get home --- great.  The possibilities: unimaginable and mind-bending lifeforms to be found on the journey home, unlike anything experienced before --- phenomenal.  Unfortunately, all of this is barely touched upon.  The journey home was like any other TNG exploration mission; there is no sense of despair, loneliness, and anxiety to get back --- stupid.  The crews work together immediately with the Maquis being integrated throughout the ships crew AND taking on the Federation uniforms --- ridiculous.  When they find lifeforms, they are almost ALL humanoids who SPEAK ENGLISH and SHARE SIMILAR cultural nuances, and all referred to by the generic term "ALIEN" --- preposterous!!  (Neelix of ALL people should have been made less "American Human".)  Where is the uniqueness in this??  (Maybe this happened a lot in TNG and TOS, but we are way beyond that now.)  What should have gracefully evolved over the course of 2-3 seasons (e.g., dire need to get home, Maquis taking on the uniform in later seasons, and finding more humanoids as an indicator of getting closer to home) was done over the course of the pilot and subsequent 2-3 episodes.  Completely rushed for no reason.  (Mind you, I hold DS9 as the pinnacle of Trek; barring the first 2 seasons, it is the best Trek, in my opinion.)  Instead this season is dumbed down, and the only real saving graces were Tuvok and The Doctor, of all people --- the least emotional. Janeway was not bad, but I can definitely accept her as captain and Chakotay would have been better off portraying a person of Mexican heritage instead because the nuances of being a Native American don't really come through this character.  Fortunately, season 2 starts turning this around with creative stories that center more on declining resources on their journey home and it provides more "reasons" for why they find humanoids so far away from Earth.  Here's hoping things get better.

I've always loved Star Trek.  When I was really little, my favorite "adult" show was The Next Generation.  Even though I could barely grasp it, there was always something appealing about it. I also watched some of Deep Space 9 on TV, which I loved, as well as Voyager.  For a few weeks I went over to my aunt's house next door & we'd watch Voyager together.  It was my least favorite at the time, but now I'd definitely rank it above TOS.  I got this after an acquaintance of mine recommended it to me.  He said that this was his favorite Star Trek after TNG, because while it was never as good as TNG, it had no bad episodes (I've seen 4 bad episodes in TNG season 1 already, & I'm sure I'll see more before I'm through).  I've halfway through season 2, & I'm inclined to agree with him.

1-2.  Caretaker:  On a mission to the Badlands, the USS Voyager, along with a Maquis ship, is stranded in the Delta Quadrant, more than 70,000 light-years from home by an incredibly powerful being known as "Caretaker."  The best pilot I've ever seen for a Star Trek show.  A

3.  Parallax:  Voyager is trapped in a quantum singularity's event horizon, and Captain Janeway must decide between Lt. Carey and former Maquis B'Elanna Torres to be the new chief engineer.  B

4.  Time and Again  Captain Kathryn Janeway and Tom Paris are sent back in time one day before an alien planet is annihilated. They attempt to stop the explosion that destroys the planet.  B+

5.  Phage:  An organ-harvesting species known as the Vidiians steal Neelix's lungs, leaving him to die.  A

6.  The Cloud: The crew enters a nebula to collect samples before realizing it is a living organism.  A-

7.  Eye of the Needle:  A micro-wormhole is discovered that leads to the Alpha Quadrant, and the crew make contact with a Romulan ship on the other side.  B+

8.  Ex Post Facto:  Tom Paris is convicted of murder on an alien world, and his punishment is reliving the murder from the victim's perspective every 14 hours.  An excellent noir episode, directed by LeVar Burton, proving that any Star Trek actor can direct better than Shatner.  A+

9.  Emanations:  Harry Kim is transported to an alien world at the same time a dead body arrives on Voyager.  A

10.  Prime Factors:  A race that could shorten Voyager's journey with a transportation device will not share its technology.  B

11.  State of Flux:  Janeway and the other senior officers attempt to flush out a spy who is sending information to the Kazon.  A

12.  Heroes & Demons:  The holographic doctor must rescue crew members who were turned to energy in the Holodeck, by entering a holodeck program of Beowulf.  I hate holodeck episodes but this was redeemed by a spotlight on my favorite character, the Doctor.  B

13.  Cathexis:  An alien mind takes over crew-members' bodies, and Chakotay is left apparently brain-dead after something attacks his shuttlecraft.  A typical plot but good enough & had a good twist.  B

14.  Faces:  B'Elanna Torres is split into her human and Klingon halves by the Vidiians.  An excellent episode, featuring one of the most gruesome deaths of a red shirt.  A+

15.  Jetrel:  A member of the Haakonians, a race warring with the Talaxians arrives on Voyager, much to the dismay of Neelix, whose family was killed by them.  My favorite episode of the season, apart from maybe Faces.  A+

16.  Learning Curve:  Tuvok trains several Maquis members who have not fully integrated into the Voyager crew.  B

Voyager takes the normal Star Trek premise, but tweaks it by cutting the ship off from the typical resources they have access to by kicking them to the other side of the galaxy. The overarching plot is their search to get home. There are some really nice episodes in the opening season.  I particularly liked "Jetrel" where an alien is faced to confront his perceptions of a genocidal event in his people's history. Another fun episode is "The 37's" where we find out what actually happened to Amelia Erhardt. These two span the spectrum of Star Trek writing, too. Jetrel is full of moral ambiguities and challenges us to think outside our own perspective where The 37's has a very positive and hopeful message. I plan on continuing the voyages of the Starship Voyager through the other six seasons.

Discipline among the crew members varies as to if they are Federation trained or Maquis rebels. Janeway suggests a field training program run by Tuvok to bring the troublesome Maquis in line and Chakotay agrees....

Neelix is forced to meet face to face with the man who he hates the most.  He was the chief scientist of the Haakonians who defeated Talax in a devastating and horrific war 15 years before. Neelix must also face his own personal demons in remembering the war and his actions at that time......

This is an OK episode but I couldn't shake the feeling that the writers were trying to bring back the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki and asking if the developers of the bomb should feel responsible and have remorse for the use of their bomb. I also felt that Janeway is always too trusting of every stranger and alien race she meets and it is a naive approach to meeting a new alien race every week.  This is still a good series and you should watch this episode as it does give tremendous insight into the character of Neelix.

Tom Paris, Torres and Ensign Durst are on an away mission and they fail to be at the pickup point on time so the Voyager can transport them back up to the ship.  They have been captured by the phage infected Vidiians.  A master surgeon has split Torres into her human and Klingon personalities to use her pure Klingon DNA to search for a clue to a cure for the phage.....

This is a very good episode and as it contains some action and a deep insight into the personality and character of B'Elanna Torres.  You finally get to see the struggle of personalities that she faced during her entire life.

This is a good episode and I recommend it to you.

Returning from an away mission, Tuvok and Chakotay arrive on the shuttle being operated by the autopilot.  Tuvok is injured but Chakotay is in a coma.  The shuttle appears to have been involved in a battle and is damaged.  The doctor examines him and finds that he can keep Chakotay alive but his brain energy is gone and he is brain dead.....

This is a pretty good episode with an alien invader with a plan that can threaten the lives of the Voyager crew.  I enjoyed this episode and it was probably a 3.5 rating but I rolled it up to a 4.  This series has not had a lot of action since the first episode that started the season.  There have been some good stories like this one and the action was higher in this one.  I recommend to you.

The Voyager alters course to investigate a protostar that is emitting photonic matter that the crew thinks will boost their power generation by 15to 20 percent. They beam aboard two samples for testing and Janeway wants the test results right away. To speed up the testing they try to find Ensign Kim but the computer tells them that he is not on the ship. His last known location was on the holodeck which is acting strangely and the safety controls are not working.

Tuvok and Chakotay are sent in to investigate what is wrong and they find the holodeck running a program on Beowulf. While looking for the missing Kim they are told that he was killed by the Grendel. When they confront the Grendel they also disappear from the ship....

This is a good story and interesting but it certainly does not carry the kind of action you would find in most Star Trek episodes. This first season is starting slowly and the story line is a strange one. Mission number one is to return back to earth which is 75 years away at top speed and yet every episode they are off course and stopping which will turn the mission into a 150 year journey. They are also having such energy problems that they cannot use the food replicators but they continue to use the holodeck in multiple episodes.

I rated this episode a 3 star rating as the story is interesting but there is not really much Sci-Fi involved in this one. It is interesting to watch but don't expect a lot of action. At least the doctor gets a major role in this mission.

The crew is on an away mission on a planet they are gathering food supplies.  There is another ship in orbit around the planet and the alien ship is shielded. Voyager uses a burst of power to expose a Kazon ship.

As the crew begins to quickly beam up for safety reasons they realize that Ensign Seska is missing.  Chakotay is looking for her in a cave and sees Kazons walking around. The Kasons shoot Chakotay as he and the ensign shoot both of them. The Voyager leaves orbit but Chakotay was injured as is recovering in sick bay.

Shorty later the Kazon ship sends out a distress call.  The voyager responds but finds only one survivor on board as they appear to have been killed while testing a Federation piece of technology.  How did they get it......

It appears that the crew of the Voyager may have a traitor on board and Tuvok and Chakotay begin an investigation.  Can it be that a trusted member of the crew is really selling Federation technology?  This is a really good story and the action begins to pick up in this episode.  I recommend it to you as a one worth watching.

As Voyager is going through the Delta Quadrant another spacecraft is coming to meet Voyager. The alien ship is sending out a distress call, not because they are in distress but because the Voyager is in distress in the alien captain's words. The other ship's captain wants to come aboard, bring gifts and make an offer they can't turn down.

They are from the planet Sikaria and he offers that they come to their planet and have a vacation and take shore leave.  Captain Janeway easily agrees and the Sikarians offers the crew gifts. They want Janeway and the officers to stay on the planet for dinner as their guests. Kim has met a woman who is a scientist and they hit it off. She takes him to the woods and wants to hear his stories which are considered an entertainment treasure on their world. The suns come up and two suns rise in the morning sky and Kim realizes that they are on a different planet.  They teleported 40,000 light years in less than a second......

Living by the Federation Prime directive suddenly has a different meaning when the crew realizes they are the race with inferior technology.  What they refuse to give to other needy races is now denied to them and it could save the crew decades of travel on the way home.  This is a good episode with a good storyline.  It was interesting to see the shoe on the other foot so to speak.  This episode is a 4 star one and it is worth watching.

The crew thinks that they have discovered a new element that is extremely dense and would create a super strong spacecraft hull that would be indestructible.  The element is located in the asteroid rings of a very large planet in the solar system ahead of them.  The material is in some caverns inside of the asteroids. When they beam into the caverns they find that the caverns are filled with webs and hundreds of dead humanoid bodies wrapped in the same webs.

Torres, Kim and Chakotay find the bodies and while they are examining them a dimensional subspace opening occurs and lights up the cavern. For safety reasons they are transporting to the Voyager at the same time and Chakotay and Torres arrive but Harry Kim is missing and replaced by a dead alien body on the transporter pad.......

This is not a bad story and it leads to the insight of an alien religious belief and how it affects their behavior and culture.  It is worth watching and it is a fairly good story.

Harry Kim and Tom Paris are on a mission on the planet Benean to have a key navigation system repaired.  Tom is accused of murdering the top scientist/professor who is helping them fix the device.  The motive to the crime is that older professor has a beautiful and younger wife that Tom falls for.  Tom is sentenced in the Benean's way of punishment and is forced to relive the last moments of his victims life and death over and over.

Janeway asks Tuvok to prove Tom's innocence before the conviction penalty destroys his mind and his sanity......

This episode is just OK to me as it did not really involve much Sci-Fi.  It is more of mystery theatre style of program and while it was good it is not what you are expecting from a good Star Trek episode.  I rate this as a three star episode.  You should watch it but it was just average for me.

While heading home from the Delta Quadrant Harry Kim has found a stationary wormhole. They have to change course to see if it is one they can pass through and perhaps find a shortcut back home. They arrive at the worm hole only to find that it is very small and caused by a micro singularity.  It is only 30 cm in diameter (A little less than one foot in diameter).  They won't fit through it but perhaps they can send a message back home. And to test this theory they send a micro probe through the hole. The worm hole may be ancient and been collapsing for centuries. The probe gets stuck but it is scanned by someone on the other side.

The probe cannot free itself and will be crushed in 72 hours. They try to transmit a message to whoever is on the other side using the probe as a re-transmitter. Star Trek Voyager was the first Star Trek franchise I never bothered to finish. I even watched all 4 seasons of Enterprise on Netflix. However, Voyager just never rose beyond a mediocrity. The whole premise was that the ship was stranded in the Delta Quadrant, far from home, but we never actually see any implications of this. There is almost no tension amongst the crew, no divisions, no infighting. Starfleet discipline is maintained even when it doesn't make sense. Very few families or deep relationships forming, something absolutely impossible in such close quarters. The show could have gone off in an interesting direction, but instead became a more action-oriented Next Generation.

Given that the producers decided to take the show in an episodic rather than serial format, the show needed something other than the plotline to make it interesting. However, the crew is for the most part an utterly boring bunch. Katherine Janeway is fine as the ship's captain, emanating a motherly concern for the crew, but can't hold a candle to Captains Picard or Sisko. The holographic doctor is ironically the most interesting and entertaining character. He provides much-needed humor. However, the rest of the crew shows little to no character development. They're usually relegated to restating the obvious.

Voyager was partly a victim of more cynical viewer attitudes in the late 1990s and the rise of reality TV. However, Voyager also failed on its own grounds. Coming after TNG and DS9, Voyager needed to more than just another Star Trek.

When Voyager first hit the airways I was not impressed.  TO be honest, Janeway was the reason why.  She was extremely stiff and inflexible in the first season; even more than Picard in TNG.  But I was so head-in-clouds over Deep Space Nine and Babylon 5 that I acknowledged not really giving the show a fair chance.  So I decided to watch it from the beginning.  And I will write high level reviews for each season, not each episode.

Season 1's focus is the crew getting adjusted to life in the Delta Quadrant as well as the merging of Maquis and Starfleet members into a cohesive crew.  This struggle makes for some good writing early on as you would definitely expect some conflicts, but there were some missed opportunities for sabotage.  Episodes like "State of Flux" which sets the foundation for one of the most interesting backstories in Voyager (Seska) and "Learning Curve" where they showcase some stragglers that just didn't make the full transition to Starfleet life.  The most obvious negative is that they never fully explored the latter; after a while, people just start flowing along happily, which given the story of the Maquis told in Deep Space Nine, should really been more challenging.

There were some head scratcher episodes, such as "Time and Again" where it causes a headache thinking about what's going on (which is the reason it's generally not a good idea to tell a time travel-related story), and you can't help but think back to TNG's "Time's Arrow" where Data experiences generally the same idea; that you can encounter an event today that both hasn't and has happened.  Trust me when I say that the episode does make sense, but it will give you some migraines trying to sort through the chronology of everything.  Even worse is the idea that Janeway can affect the flow of time by realizing the paradox, thus preventing the event that caused them to be in the situation in the first place (thus creating another paradox).

Other episodes, like "Emanations" are filler and do little to further the series.  Annoyances that are better left out of the canon, but we're stuck with nonetheless.  "Prime Factors" is actually a well-told story marred by poor character interactions and illogical behavior (Tuvok).

It's clear from the episode progression that the writers were trying to use this opportunity to work with characters and storylines that they could not have in the other Star Trek versions.  Being in the Delta Quadrant meant they could make up characters at a whim, and throwing the Maquis in there gave them "bad guys" without much effort.  The problem is that the approach is so haphazard that it will be difficult to really be interested in seeing more seasons, but the first season is necessary to really enjoy some of what comes later.

If you're reading this, you probably already know what Voyager is all about, and whether or not you like it. Season 1, as with first seasons of most TV shows, finds the producers, writers and cast seeking their footing with the concept and the characters. Thus, it's one of the weaker seasons of the series. I'm OK with that -- they had to start somewhere. Four stars for the content.

I take issue with the price. This season aired 17 years ago. It's only 15 episodes (all subsequent seasons featured 26 episodes, I think) on five DVDs. Why is it currently priced at more than $51 (a figure that randomly jumps to more than $60)? That's more than $3.40 per episode at the current price.

In addition, the DVD packaging of the Voyager series is disgraceful and insulting to the legacy of the series. It's packaged as if the product was meant to be temporary and disposable, which makes the pricing even more frustrating and unfathomable.

One would think that the first season would be most likely of all the seasons to be "value" priced in order to hook consumers into starting -- and continuing -- a collection of the complete series. Sadly, not the case here. A frustrating side-effect of this greedy pricing model is that Voyager box sets are one of the most bootlegged DVD sets you can find. Just try to buy new or used, supposedly legit copies on auction sites and you'll see what I mean. You'll probably spend about $20-$35, but there's no telling what you'll get for your money. If the price was reasonable for the official product, maybe there would be less of a market for bootlegs.

Paramount should do right by the fans of Voyager and the Star Trek franchise, a franchise which fans have made one of the most lucrative in the history of entertainment media.

I am one of many of the biggest Trekkies out here and this was the best rating I could muster for this series. As for the show itself, I fully agree with all the highest star ratings. I was a dedicated fan when it was on the air and watched any reruns as they aired as well. But, I'm a believer in keeping up with technology especially when its so obviously available. And in my opinion it sucks to open the crap packaging, insert the first disc only to realize I paid good money for an aspect ratio that is antiquated beyond current memory. I haven't had a 1.33:1 aspect (square) screen TV in over 15 years and own no DVD's that aren't widescreen. For all the technical wowzer that any Star Trek production is, or should be, I find it hard to believe it is only available in stone age format. Yet, the original series with Kirk and Co. is available in BluRay. As a die-hard Trek fan, I watched the entire 7 seasons of Voyager when it originally aired.  At the time, I was a bit disappointed in the show.  It seemed like a bit of a Next Gen retread, and some of the characters were annoying (like Neelix, who was Trek's equivalent of Jar Jar Binks).  I also grew weary of the constant techno-babble and the way every crew member seemed to be totally proficient in PHD level astro-physics.

Anyway, I bought the DVD set mostly because I got a great deal on it at Walmart, but was pleasantly surprised at how good it was in 2011.  All the stuff that annoyed me before didn't seem so bad now that the show has some distance from its predecessors.  It was also refreshing to see a show which aimed high from a moral standpoint and openly defended their principles no matter what the cost.  Most of the recent sci-fi shows are far more complex and ambiguous in that respect, so it's nice to see a command crew that isn't saddled with all kinds of personal demons and conflicting agendas.

I also liked Kate Mulgrew a lot more this time around.  Where I found her abrasive before I now see her as bold and decisive.  And one of the coolest things about this set is the bonus disc that contains footage of the original actress (Catherine Bujold) who was tapped to play Janeway.  I remember reading about her back when this aired.  They said she couldn't handle the rigors of filming a weekly TV show, and quit after only one week of shooting. But after watching the videos of her, it's clear that she was let go because she wasn't suited to the part at all, and Kate Mulgrew is brilliant by comparison.

One knock on this set is the video quality, which is not great by today's high-def standards.  Like STNG and DS9, it was shot on film but the final edits were done on video tape.  So the final "masters" are of inferior quality, and the only way to fix it is to go back and rebuild the special effects + live action compilation from scratch using modern technology.  From what I've read, there's no plan to do that (not surprising, as Paramount is always dragging its feet and Voyager wasn't that popular to begin with). So odds are, this set is as good as it will get anytime soon.

As others have pointed out, the packaging is a bit on the flimsy side, but it's not as bad as some reviewers have suggested.  As long as it's handled carefully, the box and colored panels hold up well enough and the whole thing looks really cool in the box.

So all in all, I'd give this a thumbs up.  The price has come down to a reasonable amount, and the bonus disc has a bunch of cool interviews with the producers, along with the original Janeway footage mentioned above.  Unfortuately, this set is new very hard to find out in retail world.  Music & video stores are on the decline in general, and the only big-box retailed I know of who carried Voyager was Walmart (and they dropped it from their inventory last year).  So at this point, it's pretty much Amazon or Ebay if you want to buy this set new.  And if you get it from Amazon, at least you'll know that you can easily exchange it if you do happen to receive a damaged box.  I'd get it while you can - this probably is out of print and whatever copies are left are all there will be for quite some time.

Please note: my two-star review is with regard to the overall DVD experience. I recently purchased season one of Star Trek: Voyager, and almost immediately upon opening the set to view when getting home, I realized (again) why I waited so long to start collecting any of the Star Trek series on DVD.

For starters, I remember very vividly the days in 2002, 2003 when television series -- both old and new -- were popping out season sets on DVD for roughly $40.00 to $50.00 per season. At the time, that seemed to be the reasonable standard. Paramount in it's infinite wisdom (or would that be greed?) managed to find a way to charge upwards of $150.00 per season for any of the Star Trek sets. And, much as I love Star Trek, I certainly wasn't about to spend that kind of money on any of these sets, and Voyager is the embodiment of that reasoning.

The obvious jugular to go for in this case would be the packaging. It's downright atrocious. Flimsy, gaudy, and cheap. Season One is packaged in two, transparent slip cases which are really just ONE slip case that has been halved in the middle. Removing these pieces reveals the translucent, electric orange DVD jewel-case "book" for the five discs. "Book" being entirely facetious because upon closer inspection the only thing binding these orange "pages" together is a piece of transparent packaging tape.

The discs themselves are poorly labeled. Where in all previous releases for TOS, TNG and DS9, there were actual labels on the discs and sometimes even episode listings, the Voyager discs instead have the show logo printed and little else. What else there*is* on the disc is printed in so minuscule a font, it might as well not even be there.

The first season, consisting of the first sixteen hours of the series (the two-hour pilot telefilm plus fourteen regular episodes) are presented in airdate order (to the best of my recollection). At first the episodes look terrible but I attribute that more to being spoiled by the clarity and wonderful-ness of Blu-Ray on HD televisions. The visual effects still look great and once they finally settled on a hairdo for Janeway, most of the distracting visual elements cease to be distracting.

In terms of storytelling and overall quality, I've found that your mileage will vary. Not strictly from episode to episode alone but on the whole. Until reviewing the series on DVD this week, I'd not actually seen most of these episodes in maybe nine or ten years. I fondly recalled "Caretaker" being a very good first show and that the first year itself had been quite strong and well written. Perhaps it's the passage of time, perhaps my storytelling sensibilities have changed in the intervening years, but the shows didn't seem to 'pop' as much as they once had. Standouts like "Heroes & Demons," "State of Flux," and "Jetrel" are anchored down by the mostly mediocre efforts like "Emanations" and "Learning Curve."

The special features are nice, and there are a few "hidden" Easter Egg features as well that are really just minute-long blurbs from various cast and crew members recollecting about some tidbit of trivia from the show's production. A nice touch that could have (and some say SHOULD have) been included --and one that would perhaps justify the hefty pricetag-- would be to include the previous series' introductory episodes to the Maquis conflict -- TNG's "Journey's End" and "Preemptive Strike" along with DS9's "The Maquis" two-parter. Sadly, there's nothing like that on this set.

So in conclusion, while some of the stories have aged rather well given how timely and topical they were in the '90s, some have not. And while some of the special features clearly had some forethought and effort expended in to producing them, the physical packaging of this DVD set clearly did not. Overall, I find this set is most certainly not worth some of the more extreme price tags that come attached to it. If you simply must have it, try to find the set for under $20.00.

Bashing Voyager is pretty much the national pastime as far as Trek is concerned.  People warned me away from this show for years.  My thinking was "how bad could it be?  It was on the air for seven seasons without getting cancelled."  After seeing this season, my question is "Why didn't it get cancelled?  The writing is some of the worst I've ever seen in my life.  It was almost like they were trying to write a bad plot in every episode.  I don't like too many of the characters that much, except for the Doctor.  Janeway is a worse captain than the Enterprise-B captain from Generations.

 Okay, let me start at the beginning.  The new U.S.S. Voyager and a Maquis ship get caught in some kind of nexus-like thing and are transported to the delta quadrant.  They find some guy called the caretaker who transports ships to himself....for some reason.  They find the Caretaker and have the opportunity to use his technology to get back home, but no.  Janeway says they have to destroy the array because they have to keep it from being used by the Kazon.  Which, without question, goes against the prime directive.  You know, that federation law, which says we aren't allowed to interfere in other cultures?  Janeway says that "We're already involved" and blows the array to bits.  If she absolutely had to destroy the array, why didn't she stay behind and do it herself?  Or make a fuse or something.  But no, Janeway did what she does best.  She took a situation with a fairly obvious solution and instead of going with that solution, she followed the solution that was the most idiotic.  She continues to do that throughout the season.  I'm not a big fan of the thing with Voyager being stranded far from home.  I don't see why this is any different from TOS or TNG where they're out exploring the unknown.  They're doing the exact same thing here, except they are also trying to find a way to get home.  This is supposed to make the series new and exciting, but to me it just made it worse.  Because we're going to have all these "will voyager make it home" episodes.  And since it isn't the series finale, we know they aren't going to make it home.  Not yet, anyway.  In a way, this almost makes the series depressing, because we know these morons are going to have to spend the next seven years with each other.

 Along those lines, let me talk about the characters.  As I said earlier, I love the Doctor.  Picardo steals every scene he is in, with his horrible bedside manner and his sarcasm.  But other than him, there's almost no character I like.  There were some characters I thought were okay.  Kes is supposed to be this sweet, likeable character that everyone likes.  And she is, except when she's annoying about it.  She cares about the doctor, and wants to make him as comfortable as possible.  Why?  He's a hologram, nothing more.  He's not someone who needs to be comforted or cuddled.  Kes is sweet, yes, but moronically so.  Tuvok was okay, I guess.  He's really nothing more than your standard Vulcan.  There really isn't anything about him that makes him any different than Spock.  Except that he's a lot less interesting than Spock.  It was like they had to come up with an idea for a new character, and they were tired so they said "Why don't we just throw a Vulcan into the mix?  We haven't had a Vulcan in the last two shows."  The thing is, I think most Vulcans are kind of bland.  All they do is repeat "logic" and "no emotion".  What made Spock so interesting was the fact that he is half-human, and strives to constantly keep his human side in check.  But other than him, I don't find most Vulcans very interesting.  And Tuvok is no exception.  Torres is okay, but why is it that almost every Trek series has to have a crew member of a mixed race?  It's been done before.  Except now we get a half-human, half-klingon chick.  She has to struggle to keep her klingon side in check, blah blah blah........like I said, we've seen this before.  It's already been done, and done better.  The last character I didn't hate is Chakotay.  He isn't a great character, to say the least.  And he seems to have a crush on Janeway, since he goes along with every retarded plan she comes up with.  But I found his character to be somewhat interesting.  Although sometimes they get a little bit racist with his animal guide stuff.

 I hate Harry Kim and Tom Paris.  I thought Tom's background was kind of interesting, but he is by far the worst actor on this show.  And that's saying something.  Whenever he delivers a well-written line (which isn't often given the writing) it backfires because the guy simply cannot act.  He's horrible.  The guy who plays Harry Kim is not much better, but the problems I have with his character are more the writing than the bad performance.  Harry Kim is the nerd that you knew in high school who always got stuffed in a locker by the jocks.  He's the butt of every joke, and I wish they would just kill him off already and put him out of his misery.  But the two worst characters in this show by far are Janeway and Neelix.  The sad thing is, neither one of these actors are bad.  Both of them are decent actors.  But their characters are written so badly.  Let's start with Neelix.  Neelix is more annoying than Jar Jar Binks and Wesley Crusher combined.  He weasel's his way onto the ship first as a guide, and then as morale officer.  He imposes his authority over everyone, including Janeway.  And you want to know the most infuriating part of all this?  Everyone goes along with it!!  The only one who ever takes a stand against this jerk is Seska, and she's evil.  And since she also hates Janeway for getting them lost in the first place....I might be in love with her.  Along those lines, Janeway is a horrible captain.  She faces any problem, big or small, and does the following.  She searches for the most destructive, painful solution that will probably be the most destructive and cause the biggest loss of life.  And she always has to go out of her way to get all these worthless people onto the ship.  Like when she got Tom Paris out of the penal colony to come with them on the mission, for absolutely no reason.  And why does she integrate the Maquis into the Voyager crew?  Why not do what any sensible captain would do and throw them in the brig?  She puts Chakotay, a renegade, in the first officer position, rather than Tuvok, who has had starfleet training and is the second officer.

 Another problem this show has is the lack of effective villians.  The two groups of villians are the Kazon and the Viidians.  The Kazon are a joke.  They are complete and utter morons.  The Viidians are kind of interesting, because they're not necessarily bad.  They're just doing what they have to to survive.  But just like the Kazon, they are not very smart.  The only villian I liked was Seska.  The reason she is so effective is because she's so smart.  Or it could be that she looks smart when compared to the Kazon and the Viidians.  Voyager is a bad show, because both the writing and the characters are horrible.  How this crap ran for seven seasons is beyond me.  But I've said all that to say this:  I actually found myself enjoying this show.  It's one of the worst things I've ever seen, but for some reason I like it.  A lot of the episodes had crappy storylines, but only because they didn't make good use of what they had.  They would have an interesting idea, and then dump bad writing or cliches on top of that.  This was not a good season, but it was at least better than season one of TNG.  Man, that season was the textbook definition of bad Science Fiction.  And TNG eventually did develop into a very good series.  Maybe I'll find the later seasons of Voyager enjoyable too.
